segment.source: Set up a kiosk on Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, or Education (Windows 10)
segment.target: Set up a kiosk on Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, or Education (Windows 10)

segment.source: A single-use device is easy to set up in Windows 10 for desktop editions (Pro, Enterprise, and Education).
segment.target: A single-use device is easy to set up in Windows 10 for desktop editions (Pro, Enterprise, and Education).

segment.source: Set up a kiosk on Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, or Education
segment.target: Set up a kiosk on Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, or Education

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Looking for Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry information?
segment.target: Looking for Windows Embedded 8.1 Industry information?

segment.source: See Assigned Access
segment.target: See Assigned Access

segment.source: A single-use device is easy to set up in Windows 10 for desktop editions (Pro, Enterprise, and Education).
segment.target: A single-use device is easy to set up in Windows 10 for desktop editions (Pro, Enterprise, and Education).

segment.source: For a kiosk device to run a Universal Windows app, use the assigned access feature.
segment.target: For a kiosk device to run a Universal Windows app, use the assigned access feature.

segment.source: For a kiosk device (Windows 10 Enterprise or Education) to run a Classic Windows application, use Shell Launcher to set a custom user interface as the shell.
segment.target: For a kiosk device (Windows 10 Enterprise or Education) to run a Classic Windows application, use Shell Launcher to set a custom user interface as the shell.

segment.source: To return the device to the regular shell, see Sign out of assigned access.
segment.target: To return the device to the regular shell, see Sign out of assigned access.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: A Universal Windows app is built on the Universal Windows Platform (UWP), which was first introduced in Windows 8 as the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: A Universal Windows app is built on the Universal Windows Platform (UWP), which was first introduced in Windows 8 as the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: A Classic Windows application uses the Classic Windows Platform (CWP) (e.g., COM, Win32, WPF, WinForms, etc.) and is typically launched using an .EXE or .DLL file.
segment.target: A Classic Windows application uses the Classic Windows Platform (CWP) (e.g., COM, Win32, WPF, WinForms, etc.) and is typically launched using an .EXE or .DLL file.

segment.source: Other settings to lock down
segment.target: Other settings to lock down

segment.source: For a more secure kiosk experience, we recommend that you make the following configuration changes to the device:
segment.target: For a more secure kiosk experience, we recommend that you make the following configuration changes to the device:

segment.source: Put device in Tablet mode.
segment.target: Put device in Tablet mode.

segment.source: If you want users to be able to use the touch (on screen) keyboard, go to SettingsSystemTablet mode and choose On.
segment.target: If you want users to be able to use the touch (on screen) keyboard, go to SettingsSystemTablet mode and choose On.

segment.source: Hide Ease of access feature on the logon screen.
segment.target: Hide Ease of access feature on the logon screen.

segment.source: Go to Control PanelEase of AccessEase of Access Center, and turn off all accessibility tools.
segment.target: Go to Control PanelEase of AccessEase of Access Center, and turn off all accessibility tools.

segment.source: Disable the hardware power button.
segment.target: Disable the hardware power button.

segment.source: Go to Power OptionsChoose what the power button does, change the setting to Do nothing, and then Save changes.
segment.target: Go to Power OptionsChoose what the power button does, change the setting to Do nothing, and then Save changes.

segment.source: Remove the power button from the sign-in screen.
segment.target: Remove the power button from the sign-in screen.

segment.source: Go to Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity OptionsShutdown: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on and select Disabled.
segment.target: Go to Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity OptionsShutdown: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on and select Disabled.

segment.source: Disable the camera.
segment.target: Disable the camera.

segment.source: Go to SettingsPrivacyCamera, and turn off Let apps use my camera.
segment.target: Go to SettingsPrivacyCamera, and turn off Let apps use my camera.

segment.source: Turn off app notifications on the lock screen.
segment.target: Turn off app notifications on the lock screen.

segment.source: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemLogonTurn off app notifications on the lock screen.
segment.target: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemLogonTurn off app notifications on the lock screen.

segment.source: Disable removable media.
segment.target: Disable removable media.

segment.source: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice InstallationDevice Installation Restrictions.
segment.target: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice InstallationDevice Installation Restrictions.

segment.source: Review the policy settings available in Device Installation Restrictions for the settings applicable to your situation.
segment.target: Review the policy settings available in Device Installation Restrictions for the settings applicable to your situation.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To prevent this policy from affecting a member of the Administrators group, in Device Installation Restrictions, enable Allow administrators to override Device Installation Restriction policies.
segment.target: To prevent this policy from affecting a member of the Administrators group, in Device Installation Restrictions, enable Allow administrators to override Device Installation Restriction policies.

segment.source: Assigned access method for Universal Windows apps
segment.target: Assigned access method for Universal Windows apps

segment.source: Using assigned access, Windows 10 runs the designated Universal Windows app above the lockscreen, so that the assigned access account has no access to any other functionality on the device.
segment.target: Using assigned access, Windows 10 runs the designated Universal Windows app above the lockscreen, so that the assigned access account has no access to any other functionality on the device.

segment.source: You have these choices for setting up assigned access:
segment.target: You have these choices for setting up assigned access:

segment.source: Use Settings on the PC - Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, and Education
segment.target: Use Settings on the PC - Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, and Education

segment.source: Apply a mobile device management (MDM) policy - Windows 10 Enterprise and Education
segment.target: Apply a mobile device management (MDM) policy - Windows 10 Enterprise and Education

segment.source: Create a provisioning package using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) - Windows 10 Enterprise and Education
segment.target: Create a provisioning package using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) - Windows 10 Enterprise and Education

segment.source: Run a PowerShell script - Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, and Education
segment.target: Run a PowerShell script - Windows 10 Pro, Enterprise, and Education

segment.source: Requirements
segment.target: Requirements

segment.source: A domain or local user account.
segment.target: A domain or local user account.

segment.source: The user account must have logged on at least once before you set up assigned access, or no apps will be available for that account.
segment.target: The user account must have logged on at least once before you set up assigned access, or no apps will be available for that account.

segment.source: To set up assigned access using MDM, you need the user account (domainaccount).
segment.target: To set up assigned access using MDM, you need the user account (domainaccount).

segment.source: A Universal Windows app that is installed for that account and is an above lock screen app.
segment.target: A Universal Windows app that is installed for that account and is an above lock screen app.

segment.source: For details on building an above lock screen app, see Kiosk apps for assigned access: Best practices.
segment.target: For details on building an above lock screen app, see Kiosk apps for assigned access: Best practices.

segment.source: The app can be your own company app that you have made available in your own app Store.
segment.target: The app can be your own company app that you have made available in your own app Store.

segment.source: To set up assigned access using MDM or PowerShell, you also need the Application User Model ID (AUMID) for the app.
segment.target: To set up assigned access using MDM or PowerShell, you also need the Application User Model ID (AUMID) for the app.

segment.source: Learn how to get the AUMID.
segment.target: Learn how to get the AUMID.

segment.source: The Universal Windows app must be able to handle multiple views and cannot launch other apps or dialogs.
segment.target: The Universal Windows app must be able to handle multiple views and cannot launch other apps or dialogs.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Assigned access does not work on a device that is connected to more than one monitor.
segment.target: Assigned access does not work on a device that is connected to more than one monitor.

segment.source: Set up assigned access in PC settings
segment.target: Set up assigned access in PC settings

segment.source: Go to StartSettingsAccountsOther users.
segment.target: Go to StartSettingsAccountsOther users.

segment.source: Choose Set up assigned access.
segment.target: Choose Set up assigned access.

segment.source: Choose an account.
segment.target: Choose an account.

segment.source: Choose an app.
segment.target: Choose an app.

segment.source: Only apps that can run above the lock screen will be displayed.
segment.target: Only apps that can run above the lock screen will be displayed.

segment.source: Close Settings – your choices are saved automatically, and will be applied the next time that user account logs on.
segment.target: Close Settings – your choices are saved automatically, and will be applied the next time that user account logs on.

segment.source: To remove assigned access, in step 3, choose Don't use assigned access.
segment.target: To remove assigned access, in step 3, choose Don't use assigned access.

segment.source: Set up assigned access in MDM
segment.target: Set up assigned access in MDM

segment.source: Assigned Access has one setting, KioskModeApp.
segment.target: Assigned Access has one setting, KioskModeApp.

segment.source: In the KioskModeApp setting, you enter the user account name and AUMID for the app to run in kiosk mode.
segment.target: In the KioskModeApp setting, you enter the user account name and AUMID for the app to run in kiosk mode.

segment.source: Learn how to get the AUMID.
segment.target: Learn how to get the AUMID.

segment.source: See the technical reference for the Assigned Access configuration service provider.
segment.target: See the technical reference for the Assigned Access configuration service provider.

segment.source: Set up assigned access using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)
segment.target: Set up assigned access using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)

segment.source: Use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 to create a provisioning package that configures a device as a kiosk.
segment.target: Use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 to create a provisioning package that configures a device as a kiosk.

segment.source: Install the ADK.
segment.target: Install the ADK.

segment.source: Create a provisioning package for a kiosk device
segment.target: Create a provisioning package for a kiosk device

segment.source: Open Windows ICD (by default, %windir%Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86ICD.exe).
segment.target: Open Windows ICD (by default, %windir%Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86ICD.exe).

segment.source: Choose New provisioning package.
segment.target: Choose New provisioning package.

segment.source: Name your project, and click Next.
segment.target: Name your project, and click Next.

segment.source: Choose Common to all Windows desktop editions and click Next.
segment.target: Choose Common to all Windows desktop editions and click Next.

segment.source: On New project, click Finish.
segment.target: On New project, click Finish.

segment.source: The workspace for your package opens.
segment.target: The workspace for your package opens.

segment.source: Expand Runtime settingsAssignedAccess, and click AssignedAccessSettings.
segment.target: Expand Runtime settingsAssignedAccess, and click AssignedAccessSettings.

segment.source: Enter a string to specify the user account and app (by AUMID).
segment.target: Enter a string to specify the user account and app (by AUMID).

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: "Account":"contosokiosk","AUMID":"8f82d991-f842-44c3-9a95-521b58fc2084"
segment.target: "Account":"contosokiosk","AUMID":"8f82d991-f842-44c3-9a95-521b58fc2084"

segment.source: On the File menu, select Save.
segment.target: On the File menu, select Save.

segment.source: On the Export menu, select Provisioning package.
segment.target: On the Export menu, select Provisioning package.

segment.source: Change Owner to IT Admin, which will set the precedence of this provisioning package higher than provisioning packages applied to this device from other sources, and then select Next.
segment.target: Change Owner to IT Admin, which will set the precedence of this provisioning package higher than provisioning packages applied to this device from other sources, and then select Next.

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: In the Provisioning package security window, you can choose to encrypt the package and enable package signing.
segment.target: In the Provisioning package security window, you can choose to encrypt the package and enable package signing.

segment.source: Enable package encryption - If you select this option, an auto-generated password will be shown on the screen.
segment.target: Enable package encryption - If you select this option, an auto-generated password will be shown on the screen.

segment.source: Enable package signing - If you select this option, you must select a valid certificate to use for signing the package.
segment.target: Enable package signing - If you select this option, you must select a valid certificate to use for signing the package.

segment.source: You can specify the certificate by clicking Select and choosing the certificate you want to use to sign the package.
segment.target: You can specify the certificate by clicking Select and choosing the certificate you want to use to sign the package.

segment.source: Click Next to specify the output location where you want the provisioning package to go when it's built.
segment.target: Click Next to specify the output location where you want the provisioning package to go when it's built.

segment.source: By default, Windows ICD uses the project folder as the output location.
segment.target: By default, Windows ICD uses the project folder as the output location.

segment.source: Optionally, you can click Browse to change the default output location.
segment.target: Optionally, you can click Browse to change the default output location.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Click Build to start building the package.
segment.target: Click Build to start building the package.

segment.source: The provisioning package doesn't take long to build.
segment.target: The provisioning package doesn't take long to build.

segment.source: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.
segment.target: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.

segment.source: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.
segment.target: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.

segment.source: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: If your build fails, an error message will show up that includes a link to the project folder.
segment.target: If your build fails, an error message will show up that includes a link to the project folder.

segment.source: You can scan the logs to determine what caused the error.
segment.target: You can scan the logs to determine what caused the error.

segment.source: Once you fix the issue, try building the package again.
segment.target: Once you fix the issue, try building the package again.

segment.source: If your build is successful, the name of the provisioning package, output directory, and project directory will be shown.
segment.target: If your build is successful, the name of the provisioning package, output directory, and project directory will be shown.

segment.source: If you choose, you can build the provisioning package again and pick a different path for the output package.
segment.target: If you choose, you can build the provisioning package again and pick a different path for the output package.

segment.source: To do this, click Back to change the output package name and path, and then click Next to start another build.
segment.target: To do this, click Back to change the output package name and path, and then click Next to start another build.

segment.source: If you are done, click Finish to close the wizard and go back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: If you are done, click Finish to close the wizard and go back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: Apply the provisioning package
segment.target: Apply the provisioning package

segment.source: Select the provisioning package that you want to apply, double-click the file, and then allow admin privileges.
segment.target: Select the provisioning package that you want to apply, double-click the file, and then allow admin privileges.

segment.source: Consent to allow the package to be installed.
segment.target: Consent to allow the package to be installed.

segment.source: After you allow the package to be installed, the settings will be applied to the device
segment.target: After you allow the package to be installed, the settings will be applied to the device

segment.source: Learn how to apply a provisioning package in audit mode or OOBE.
segment.target: Learn how to apply a provisioning package in audit mode or OOBE.

segment.source: Set up assigned access using Windows PowerShell
segment.target: Set up assigned access using Windows PowerShell

segment.source: You can use any of the following PowerShell cmdlets to set up assigned access on multiple devices.
segment.target: You can use any of the following PowerShell cmdlets to set up assigned access on multiple devices.

segment.source: To open PowerShell on Windows 10, search for PowerShell and find Windows PowerShell Desktop app in the results.
segment.target: To open PowerShell on Windows 10, search for PowerShell and find Windows PowerShell Desktop app in the results.

segment.source: Learn how to get the AUMID.
segment.target: Learn how to get the AUMID.

segment.source: Learn how to get the SID.
segment.target: Learn how to get the SID.

segment.source: To remove assigned access, using PowerShell, run the following cmdlet.
segment.target: To remove assigned access, using PowerShell, run the following cmdlet.

segment.source: Set up automatic logon
segment.target: Set up automatic logon

segment.source: When your kiosk device restarts, whether from an update or power outage, you can log on the assigned access account manually or you can configure the device to log on to the assigned access account automatically.
segment.target: When your kiosk device restarts, whether from an update or power outage, you can log on the assigned access account manually or you can configure the device to log on to the assigned access account automatically.

segment.source: Edit the registry to have an account automatically logged on.
segment.target: Edit the registry to have an account automatically logged on.

segment.source: Open Registry Editor (regedit.exe).
segment.target: Open Registry Editor (regedit.exe).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you are not familiar with Registry Editor, learn how to modify the Windows registry.
segment.target: If you are not familiar with Registry Editor, learn how to modify the Windows registry.

segment.source: Go to
segment.target: Go to

segment.source: ****HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsNTCurrentVersionWinlogon****
segment.target: ****HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsNTCurrentVersionWinlogon****

segment.source: Set the values for the following keys.
segment.target: Set the values for the following keys.

segment.source: AutoAdminLogon: set value as 1.
segment.target: AutoAdminLogon: set value as 1.

segment.source: DefaultUserName: set value as the account that you want logged in.
segment.target: DefaultUserName: set value as the account that you want logged in.

segment.source: DefaultPassword: set value as the password for the account.
segment.target: DefaultPassword: set value as the password for the account.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If DefaultUserName and DefaultPassword aren't there, add them as NewString Value.
segment.target: If DefaultUserName and DefaultPassword aren't there, add them as NewString Value.

segment.source: DefaultDomainName: set value for domain, only for domain accounts.
segment.target: DefaultDomainName: set value for domain, only for domain accounts.

segment.source: For local accounts, do not add this key.
segment.target: For local accounts, do not add this key.

segment.source: Close Registry Editor.
segment.target: Close Registry Editor.

segment.source: The next time the computer restarts, the account will be logged on automatically.
segment.target: The next time the computer restarts, the account will be logged on automatically.

segment.source: Sign out of assigned access
segment.target: Sign out of assigned access

segment.source: To sign out of an assigned access account, press Ctrl + Alt + Del, and then sign in using another account.
segment.target: To sign out of an assigned access account, press Ctrl + Alt + Del, and then sign in using another account.

segment.source: When you press Ctrl + Alt + Del to sign out of assigned access, the kiosk app will exit automatically.
segment.target: When you press Ctrl + Alt + Del to sign out of assigned access, the kiosk app will exit automatically.

segment.source: If you sign in again as the assigned access account or wait for the login screen timeout, the kiosk app will be re-launched.
segment.target: If you sign in again as the assigned access account or wait for the login screen timeout, the kiosk app will be re-launched.

segment.source: If you press Ctrl + Alt + Del and do not sign in to another account, after a set time, assigned access will resume.
segment.target: If you press Ctrl + Alt + Del and do not sign in to another account, after a set time, assigned access will resume.

segment.source: The default time is 30 seconds, but you can change that in the following registry key:
segment.target: The default time is 30 seconds, but you can change that in the following registry key:

segment.source: ****HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionAuthenticationLogonUI****
segment.target: ****HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionAuthenticationLogonUI****

segment.source: To change the default time for assigned access to resume, add IdleTimeOut (DWORD) and enter the value data as milliseconds in hexadecimal.
segment.target: To change the default time for assigned access to resume, add IdleTimeOut (DWORD) and enter the value data as milliseconds in hexadecimal.

segment.source: Shell Launcher for Classic Windows applications
segment.target: Shell Launcher for Classic Windows applications

segment.source: Using Shell Launcher, you can configure a kiosk device that runs a Classic Windows application as the user interface.
segment.target: Using Shell Launcher, you can configure a kiosk device that runs a Classic Windows application as the user interface.

segment.source: The application that you specify replaces the default shell (explorer.exe) that usually runs when a user logs on.
segment.target: The application that you specify replaces the default shell (explorer.exe) that usually runs when a user logs on.

segment.source: Requirements
segment.target: Requirements

segment.source: A domain or local user account.
segment.target: A domain or local user account.

segment.source: A Classic Windows application that is installed for that account.
segment.target: A Classic Windows application that is installed for that account.

segment.source: The app can be your own company application or a common app like Internet Explorer.
segment.target: The app can be your own company application or a common app like Internet Explorer.

segment.source: See the technical reference for the shell launcher component.
segment.target: See the technical reference for the shell launcher component.

segment.source: Configure Shell Launcher
segment.target: Configure Shell Launcher

segment.source: To set a Classic Windows application as the shell, you first turn on the Shell Launcher feature, and then you can set your custom shell as the default using PowerShell.
segment.target: To set a Classic Windows application as the shell, you first turn on the Shell Launcher feature, and then you can set your custom shell as the default using PowerShell.

segment.source: To turn on Shell Launcher in Windows features
segment.target: To turn on Shell Launcher in Windows features

segment.source: Go to Control Panel Programs and FeaturesTurn Windows features on or off.
segment.target: Go to Control Panel Programs and FeaturesTurn Windows features on or off.

segment.source: Select Embedded Shell Launcher and OK.
segment.target: Select Embedded Shell Launcher and OK.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can turn on Shell Launcher using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM.exe) tool.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can turn on Shell Launcher using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM.exe) tool.

segment.source: To turn on Shell Launcher using DISM
segment.target: To turn on Shell Launcher using DISM

segment.source: Open a command prompt as an administrator.
segment.target: Open a command prompt as an administrator.

segment.source: Enter the following command.
segment.target: Enter the following command.

segment.source: To set your custom shell
segment.target: To set your custom shell

segment.source: Modify the following PowerShell script as appropriate.
segment.target: Modify the following PowerShell script as appropriate.

segment.source: The comments in the sample script explain the purpose of each section and tell you where you will want to change the script for your purposes.
segment.target: The comments in the sample script explain the purpose of each section and tell you where you will want to change the script for your purposes.

segment.source: Save your script with the extension .ps1, open Windows PowerShell as administrator, and run the script on the kiosk device.
segment.target: Save your script with the extension .ps1, open Windows PowerShell as administrator, and run the script on the kiosk device.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Set up a device for anyone to use
segment.target: Set up a device for anyone to use

segment.source: Set up a kiosk for Windows 10 for mobile edition
segment.target: Set up a kiosk for Windows 10 for mobile edition

segment.source: Manage and update Windows 10
segment.target: Manage and update Windows 10
